Top 20+ Matching Gift Companies: Leaders in Corporate Giving

Matching gifts are an easy way for nonprofits to earn more revenue and are also one of the most convenient corporate giving programs for companies to implement and maintain. Best of all, recent CSR trends show that companies are becoming even more generous with their programs. To show off the potential of matching gifts, we’ve compiled a list of some of the most noteworthy companies that offer outstanding corporate matching gift programs.

Of course, thousands of employers offer matching gift programs⁠, from Fortune 500 companies to local mom-and-pop businesses. What makes these top matching gift companies stand out from the crowd?

These are some key factors that play a role:

Auto-submission ⁠— How employees participate in their matching gift programs varies from company to company, and a few trend-setting businesses have gone above and beyond to simplify the process with auto-submission. Companies that offer this functionality through their corporate giving management platform empower donors to request their matches in a single click. All employees need to do is enter their corporate email addresses when prompted to by a participating nonprofit’s donation page. Check out this video for an overview of the process:

CLMA certification — Companies can become Certified Leaders in Matching Automation by working with a CLMA-certified CSR platform. This means they’ve committed to providing a seamless and intuitive user experience for matching gifts! And the easier it is for employees to get involved, the more inclined they’ll be to do so.

Low minimums ⁠— Many companies establish minimums to ensure they are matching gifts to organizations their employees are truly passionate about⁠. However, high minimums can exclude low and even mid-range donations from matching gifts, lowering participation rates. The lower the minimum donation amount for matching gift requests, the more accessible the program is to all donors.

High maximums ⁠— On the other end of the spectrum, offering high maximums also leads to increased participation among employees and optimal benefits for the nonprofits, companies, and donors who get involved. Higher maximums encourage larger donations as well as more giving overall for employees trying to hit their yearly match amount limit.

Large ratios ⁠— A matching gift ratio is the amount of match funding a donor can receive from their employer. While 1:1 is the standard match rate, some companies choose lower ratios (such as 0.5:1), and others set higher ratios (2:1, 3:1, or even 4:1) to magnify employee contributions. The higher the match rate, the larger the potential program benefits.

Note that this type of corporate giving varies from matching or challenge grants, even though they have many of the same elements. While grants have a specific timeframe in which a nonprofit must generate support from their entire donor base, matching gifts are a year-round offering that focuses on donations exclusively given by your employees. While you certainly want to offer a generous program, you’ll need to be prepared to allocate sufficient resources on an ongoing basis.

Without further ado, let’s get into our top matching gift companies⁠ and what they do well.

Matching Gift Companies with Auto-Submission Enabled

Checkr

Checkr offers employee background screening technology for companies looking to optimize their hiring processes. The solution enlists artificial intelligence to make background-checking candidates fair and efficient.

Checkr is also devoted to social good and does so by participating in corporate philanthropy and other CSR initiatives such as matching gifts. Specifically, Checkr empowers its team members to support a wide range of charitable organizations by offering an employee donation match of 1:1 to most nonprofit causes.

Highlight: This company utilizes matching gift auto-submission to significantly streamline the request process for donors.

Ginkgo Bioworks

Ginkgo Bioworks is a Boston, Massachusetts-based biotechnology company dedicated to genetic engineering for a cause. This company works to improve processes, grow better products, and enable more industrial applications for biology.

They also aim to give back to their community and the world at large by incorporating corporate giving in their business practice. With matching gifts in particular, Ginkgo Bioworks drives good by encouraging donations to nonprofit organizations with a range of missions like education, environmental, cultural, and many more.

Highlight: This company utilizes matching gift auto-submission to significantly streamline the request process for donors.

TSR Inc.

TSR Inc., also known as TSR Consulting Services, is a professional staffing consultancy that was founded in 1969. Since then, the team has provided corporate clients across the nation with expert insights in how to create an exceptional purpose-driven and people-first employee culture.

And the firm brings the same strategies to its own workforce with impactful workplace giving initiatives! The TSR business makes charitable donations and encourages its employees to get involved as well through its generous matching gift program.

Highlight: This company utilizes matching gift auto-submission to significantly streamline the request process for donors.

Gene B. Glick Company

Founded in 1947, Gene B. Glick Company is a privately-held real estate property management and development firm. This corporation currently manages over 20,000 units in apartment communities and multifamily housing developments throughout 13 states across the country, making it one of the largest property management companies today.

To give back to the communities in which the Gene B. Glick Company operates, the company makes substantial investments in corporate social responsibility efforts. These include matching employee donations through its matching program called Glick Gives, as well as other nonprofit partnerships.

Highlight: This company utilizes matching gift auto-submission to significantly streamline the request process for donors.

Matching Gift Companies with Auto-Submission Not Yet Enabled

Sanofi

Sanofi is a global healthcare company dedicated to ongoing innovation in the fight for health and against sickness. The Sanofi company participates in corporate social responsibility in many ways, one of which is matching employee donations to a range of charitable causes.

Currently, full-time employees are eligible to request corporate matches from the company for donations made between $50 and $5,000. Sanofi matches to educational institutions, health and human services, civic and community organizations, environmental causes, and select other nonprofits, and employees should request their donation matches by April 30th of the year following the one in which the gift was made.

Deloitte

Offering expert audit, consulting, tax, and advisory services to several of the world’s leading brands, Deloitte aims to make an impact that matters. And this goodwill expands beyond their clients and out into their communities and the world as a whole through their corporate philanthropy initiatives.

For example, Deloitte offers a generous corporate matching gift program in which the company agrees to encourage philanthropy among all team members by matching employee donations. Nearly all types of nonprofit organizations qualify for Deloitte match funding, with the company matching up to $32,500 per employee on a yearly basis.

Microsoft

The world’s largest software maker is the Microsoft Corporation, founded by Bill Gates in 1975. It is known for personal computers, office software, and cloud computing innovations. It employs more than 100,000 people worldwide, and is also a generous supplier of nonprofit grants. Plus, eligible organizations can access discounted software and other technology, too!

Microsoft is widely known to have one of the leading employee giving programs. Last year, the company matched more than $47 million in employee donations to a wide variety of charities. Employees looking to get their gifts matched by the Microsoft Corporation have up to 12 months following the date of their initial donations to submit their application forms.

Highlight: Microsoft has donated more than $1 billion through employee giving programs since instituting a match program.

GE Aerospace

The General Electric Company was founded in 1892 by Thomas Edison, and for many years the conglomerate operated in aviation, healthcare, power, renewable energy, additive manufacturing, and other fields. In 2024, GE completed its separation into three public companies: GE Aerospace, GE Healthcare and GE Vernova. Following the separation, the previous GE Foundation was relaunched as the GE Aerospace Foundation, celebrating a new chapter that builds on the more than 100 year-legacy of Foundation giving.

This foundation has a long history of philanthropy, too. In 1954, the GE Foundation created the first ever corporate gift matching program. Since inception the program total exceeds $1.5 billion and continues to be an important part of the giving portfolio.

Employees participating in the program must complete their requests by April 15 of the following year.

Highlight: GE created the model for corporate employee matching gift programs.

Soros Fund Management

Soros Fund Management was founded in 1969, and since then it has become one of the most profitable firms in the hedge fund industry. They invest in public equity and fixed income markets worldwide, in addition to transportation, energy, retail, and other industries.

Soros Fund Management offers the most generous limits on corporate matching gift programs. The company’s 2:1 match for employees and partners is a strong incentive for employees to give back to their communities. To remain eligible for corporate matching, requests must be made within one year of the initial donation.

Highlight: The company matches up to $100K in annual donations per employee. This dollar amount is by far the highest limit for any corporation.

BP (British Petroleum)

BP, or British Petroleum, is a British multinational corporation focused on producing and distributing oil and gas around the world. It also has invested in renewable energy sources such as biofuels and wind power.

BP offers practically every type of employee giving program and allows the general public to track which organizations receive donations in real time online. The company provides a standard 1:1 match on all donations made by employees.

Highlight: The company also offers a 100% match on all money raised by employees for charity runs, walks, etc.

Gap Inc.

The Gap Corporation, which includes Banana Republic, Old Navy, Piperlime, Athleta, and Intermix, employs 135,000 people around the world and offers a matching gift program as well as multiple types of volunteer grants.

Gap employees can request matches on donations made to almost all types of nonprofits. Match limits range from $1,000 annually for part-time employees to as much as $15,000 for full-time staff. All employees looking to get their donations matched must submit their requests within 120 days of the initial contributions.

Highlight: Gap offers one of the most comprehensive and easy to use online systems to submit match requests.

State Street Corporation

Founded in 1792, the State Street Corporation is the second oldest bank in the United States. It is a financial services and bank holding company and is one of the largest asset management companies in the world.

Its services range from personal banking and account management to business and agriculture, trust and estate management, and more.

State Street also offers nearly every type of employee giving program. The company matches all of its global employees’ donations to most types of nonprofits.

Highlight: State Street matches the fundraising efforts of its employees up to $40,000 annually.

CarMax

CarMax is a highly popular used-car retailer, with 190 locations around the United States. It was named one of the “100 Best Companies to Work For” for over a decade and employs around 25,000 people.

CarMax matches donations to nearly every type of nonprofit. In addition to their 1:1 match on all donations, the company also offers a generous volunteer grant program. Matching gift request must be submitted within 180 of the initial contribution.

Highlight: CarMax matches donations made by an employee’s dependents until they turn 26.

Johnson & Johnson

Founded in 1886, Johnson & Johnson is a medical devices, pharmaceutical, and consumer packaged goods manufacturing company. They operate in 60 countries and sell their products in over 175, while employing over 134,000 people. The company is best known for brands such as Band-Aid, Tylenol, and Neutrogena.

Johnson & Johnson matches donations to nearly every kind of nonprofit. Each of the company’s 120,000 employees, plus all retirees, are eligible to request up to $10,000 in personal contributions to be matched each year. To qualify for matching, submissions must be completed within twelve months following the initial donation date.

Highlight: A 2:1 matching ratio for current employees and a 1:1 rate for all retirees.

Choice Hotels International

Founded in 1939, Choice Hotels International is known for their affordable family hotel chains such as Comfort Inn, Comfort Suites, Quality Inn, Sleep Inn, and more. They employ over 1,000 people and are headquartered in Rockville, MD.

Choice Hotels International matches both full- and part-time employees’ gifts between $25 and $1,500. Almost all nonprofits are eligible for this corporate giving program, including K-12 educational institutions.

Highlight: Through the “Giving Time” program, Choice Hotels matches 100 hours of volunteer service with $500 to the nonprofit the employee volunteers for.

Pfizer

Pfizer is an American pharmaceutical corporation headquartered in New York City. They develop and produce medicines and vaccines, including medications such as Lyrica, Zithromax, and Celebra, and employ over 96,000 people worldwide.

Pfizer matches donations made by employees and retirees to nonprofits supporting almost any cause, including educational institutions, arts and cultural nonprofits, and environmental organizations. Employee matches must be submitted and approved by March 1st of the year following the donation.

Highlight: Pfizer’s giving programs raise $33.7 million a year with over 40,000 matching gift requests.

Capital Group

Capital Group is one of the oldest and largest investment management organizations, being founded in Los Angeles in 1931. They offer investment services for both institutional clients and individual investors, employing over 7,000 people.

Every year, Capital Group supports over 3,000 organizations through matching gift and volunteer grants.

The matching gift program at Capital Group provides 2:1 matches, which triples the donations nonprofits receive. Employees also have an entire year after their donation to submit a match request.

Highlight: Capital Group will match every donation between $100 and $5,000.

Bristol-Myers Squibb

A world-renowned American pharmaceutical company, Bristol-Myers Squibb manufactures prescription medication for cancer treatments, HIV/AIDS, cardiovascular disease, psychiatric disorders, and others. They have research and development sites all over the world, including Ireland, Japan, and India.

Bristol-Myers Squibb matches gifts dollar for dollar to organizations that focus on environmental, education, and health and human services, among others. Matching gift requests should be submitted within six months of the donation.

Highlight: At Bristol-Myers Squibb, employees are eligible to request up to $30,000 in matching gifts annually.

Coca-Cola

Coca-Cola is an American manufacturer, retailer, and marketer of nonalcoholic beverage concentrates and syrups. Their headquarters are in Atlanta, Georgia, and they employ over 61,000 people around the world.

Both full-time employees and retirees are eligible to have their donations matched at a 2:1 ratio up to $20,000 each year. Not to mention, Coca-Cola provides a lengthy submission window, with matches being accepted until February 28th of the year following the donation.

Highlight: Since its inception in 1984, Coca-Cola has donated more than $820 million to help organizations all over the world.

IBM

IBM, which stands for “International Business Machines,” is an American multinational technology company. It operates in over 170 countries and is one of the world’s largest employers, with nearly 380,000 employees. IBM is known for inventions like the ATM, the PC, the floppy disk, and the magnetic strip card.

IBM will match every donation of at least $25, dollar for dollar. Individual contributions of up to $10,000 will be matched each year. Retiree donations are matched at an all-time high ratio of 5:1, and all donation matches should be submitted within a year of the initial contribution being made.

Highlight: Everyone—full-time, part-time, and retired employees—can participate in IBM’s matching gift program.

Air Products and Chemicals

Air Products and Chemicals is an American corporation that sells chemicals and gases for industrial uses. It was named one of the 100 Best Corporate Citizens by Corporate Responsibility Magazine in 2010, and it employs around 20,000 people.

The Air Products Foundation matches donations at a 1:1 ratio, meaning employee donations will be doubled for their favorite causes. In order to remain eligible for a match, all requests should be submitted within 12 months of the donation date.

Highlight: Part-time and full-time employees can have up to $5,000 matched.

American Express

American Express, also known as Amex, is a financial services corporation known for its charge card, credit card, and traveler’s checks businesses. It was called the 23rd best company to work for by Fortune in 2018, and employs around 55,000 people worldwide.

While the standard matching gift ratio is 1:1, employees can have their donations matched at a higher ratio if they’re on a nonprofit board or volunteer more than 50 hours a year.

American Express has a minimum donation matching amount of $25.

Highlight: American Express will match gifts to organizations up to $8,000.

FM Global

FM Global is a mutual insurance company based in Rhode Island. It specializes in loss prevention services for large corporations. It was named the “best property insurer in the world” by Euromoney Magazine. FM Global has clients in more than 100 countries and over 5,500 employees.

FM Global will match gifts made by part-time, full-time, and retired employees dollar for dollar to most organizations.

Highlight: If an employee donates to an educational institution, FM Global will provide a 2:1 match.

How Double the Donation Can Increase Matching Gifts for Nonprofits

Nonprofits often miss out on receiving matching gifts revenue because donors don’t know about their employers’ matching gifts policies, with 78% of donors being unaware of whether their employer even offers a matching gift program.

Double the Donation removes the hassle of researching matching gift eligibility requirements for your donors by creating a searchable database that includes over 20,000 companies and subsidiaries.

So how does the process work?

Your supporter makes a gift.

You encourage them to look up if they are eligible for matching gifts through Double the Donation.

The supporter looks up their company.

Double the Donation’s database shows them if they are eligible and where they can find the necessary forms.

The supporter fills out the form and your nonprofit benefits!

The process can be even shorter for some supporters thanks to auto-submission. On your nonprofit’s end, you just need matching gift software. Donors who work for an employer with auto-submission enabled CSR software can make their donation, research their eligibility, and then complete their matching gift request in seconds.

How to Start Your Own Matching Gift Program: Steps for Companies

If you represent a corporation that’s interested in launching its own matching gift initiative, the above examples are excellent programs to aspire to. And each of those companies started somewhere!

Here’s how your company can begin matching gifts:

Determine gift amounts that you’re willing to match per employee, per year. This is typically done by choosing a set minimum and maximum donation size.

Identify the types of employees whose charitable donations your company will match. Specifically, determine if you’ll match gifts for just current full-time employees or extend matching gift opportunities to part-time and retired employees or even employee spouses.

Choose the nonprofit mission types your company will match donations to. Consider whether you’ll match gifts for all 501(c)(3) nonprofits, educational institutions (including or exempting K-12 programs), local charities, any organization with the exception of houses of worship, or have any other requirements.

Set a deadline by which employees must submit a matching gift request to be eligible for a company donation. This should be a certain annual date or a number of months post-donation.

Decide how employees will submit their matching gift requests and what donation information will be required. Many companies utilize online forms or CSR platforms to ask for a copy of the donation receipt and nonprofit contact information, including their EIN. If your company already uses a CSR platform, check to see if it integrates with Double the Donation’s matching gift software and get in touch with our team to learn about enabling auto-submission to make matching gifts even easier for your employees.

Promote your new matching gift program to your employees to drive participation. Share information about your giving program in your internal communications, policy handbook, onboarding materials, and other relevant internal materials.

This is a quick overview, but there are plenty of available resources if you’re looking for a more in-depth guide of what to consider when starting a matching gift program.

Offering to match employee donations is one of the simplest yet most effective ways to engage with your workforce while doing good at the same time. And companies of all shapes and sizes can partake⁠ in corporate partnerships. So, if you haven’t already, it’s time to get matching!
